summary: In this appeal from a Circuit Court decision, Afua Oforiwaa challenged the award of only a one-third share of the matrimonial home (No. D40 Abeka Lapaz) following the dissolution of her customary marriage to Paul K. Adu. The Court of Appeal held that despite a deed of gift (Exhibit 7) naming only the husband as the recipient, the property was acquired during the subsistence of the marriage and financed through a common fund derived from joint earnings in the UK and shared business ventures in Ghana. The court emphasized that both parties contributed to the family's financial well-being, with the wife working as a seamstress and cleaner and managing the household and children. Citing Article 22(3) of the 1992 Constitution and precedents such as Abebreseh v Kaah and Domfe v Adu, the Court ruled that the wife was entitled to an equal share in the matrimonial property. The appeal was allowed, and the cross-appeal dismissed due to lack of written submissions.
rationaleHighlights: The court found that both spouses contributed to a common fund, which financed property acquisition.
Despite the deed of gift naming only the husband, the property was treated as a family asset due to joint contributions.
The trial court erred in awarding only 1/3 share to the wife; she was entitled to an equal share.
Precedents from Abebreseh v Kaah and Domfe v Adu were applied to affirm equal sharing based on contribution.
